description: US carnival slang of uncertain origin. Possibly from scamp (“swindler, cheater”) or Irish cam (“crooked”). Also possibly from Danish skam; if so, it would be a doublet of shame and sham.
The word "scam" became common use among the US "drug culture" in early 1980 after Operation ABSCAM, an FBI sting operation directed at public officials, became public.

examples: That marketing scheme looks like a scam to me.

entries.meaning: Something that is promoted using scams.
examples: That new diet burger is a scam.

verbs.description: scam (third-person singular simple present scams, present participle scamming, simple past and past participle scammed)

examples: They tried to scam her out of her savings.
